work a typical USB device has something called a USB device controller and it's
an integrated circuit that is what actually runs the USB connection so
you'll have a connector on a device and then there's a USB device controller uh attached to the connector
with a with a few line traces on the printed circuit board and then there it's talks to some CPU uh and that CPU
may be actually on in the same integrated package we see a lot of microcontrollers that have an integrated
USB device controller so so those two things might actually be one IC um but
typically you'll see that device controller connected directly to the USB connector so if you plug into the USB
connector you're talking to the device controller now mobile phones and tablets
in recent years have started to do things a little bit differently there's a CPU and it has a
US USB device controller but it does not directly connect to the USB connector in
between the two is a multiplexer IC an integrated circuit that detects what
type of thing is plugged into the connector and redirects the connection or switches it between the USB device
controller and various other functions and we think this is very
interesting as a potential attack surface um we've seen some interesting
attacks on USB hosts in recent years like Travis goodspeed's face dancer
project has exposed a lot of interesting stuff uh so you can plug into a device and attack its USB stack that's an
interesting attack surface on its own but we've discovered that there is a much greater attack surface USB is just
one of the functions that you can reach from that USB port and we're finding
other things um in particular
uh the multiplex functions that are handled by that multiplexer IC uh that
are commonly seen one is USB on the go which is a way for it to automatically
switch between host mode and device mode and another is audio where the the USB
car kit standard actually allows the USB connector to carry audio data in an

a connectors that are on your uh computers your desktops your laptops
have four pins but the newer micro USB connectors and mini USB connectors have

originally intended for USB on the go it'll you connect um in a in the plug of a
cable if you're making a cable you connect the ID pin to ground if you want
that to tell that cable to tell that device you're plugging into to switch into host mode or you leave the ID pin
unconnected and plug that in and the device assumes that it's in device mode
and that's the crudest form of accessory detection and people have extended that
